elements.content: Ligands with flexible conformations add to the structural diversity of metal–organic frameworks but, at the same time, pose a challenge to structural design and prediction. Representative examples include Zr-tetracarboxylate-based MOFs, which afford assorted structures for a wide range of applications, but also complicate the structural control. Herein, we systematically studied the formation mechanism of a series of (4,8)-connected Zr-tetracarboxylate-based MOFs by altering the substituents on different positions of the organic linkers. Different ligand rotamers give rise to three types of structures with flu, scu, and csq topologies. A combination of experiment and molecular simulation indicate that the steric hindrance of the substituents at different positions dictates the resulting MOF structures. Additionally, the controllable formation of different structures was successfully implemented by a combination of linkers with different steric effects at specific positions.
elements.clean_text: Ligands with flexible conformations add to the structural diversity of metal-organic frameworks but, at the same time, pose a challenge to structural design and prediction. Representative examples include Zr-tetracarboxylate-based MOFs, which afford assorted structures for a wide range of applications, but also complicate the structural control. Herein, we systematically studied the formation mechanism of a series of (4,8)-connected Zr-tetracarboxylate-based MOFs by altering the substituents on different positions of the organic linkers. Different ligand rotamers give rise to three types of structures with flu, scu, and csq topologies. A combination of experiment and molecular simulation indicate that the steric hindrance of the substituents at different positions dictates the resulting MOF structures. Additionally, the controllable formation of different structures was successfully implemented by a combination of linkers with different steric effects at specific positions.

elements.content: As a new class of highly porous crystalline materials, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have rapidly developed in the past two decades due to their potential applications in gas storage, separation, light harvesting, and catalysis. MOFs epitomize unlimited tunability at the submolecular level by judicious design of metal nodes and organic linkers. Exquisite combinations of designed organic ligands with selected inorganic secondary building units (SBU) give rise to numerous MOFs with diverse structures. Taking a simple linear dicarboxylate ligand, BDC (BDC = terephthalate), as an example, a series of MOFs (MOF-5, MIL-101, and UIO-66) result from the combination of this ligand with different SBUs (Zn4O; M3O, M = Fe, Al, In, Cr, etc.; and Zr6O4(OH)4). More importantly, MOF structures are significantly diversified when considering the almost infinite number of organic ligands. The geometry and connectivity of a linker often dictates the structure of the resulting MOF. Therefore, adjustments to linker geometry, length, and functional-group can tune the size, shape, and internal surface properties of a MOF for targeted applications.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

As a new class of highly porous crystalline materials, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have rapidly developed in the past two decades due to their potential applications in gas storage, separation, light harvesting, and catalysis. MOFs epitomize unlimited tunability at the submolecular level by judicious design of metal nodes and organic linkers. Exquisite combinations of designed organic ligands with selected inorganic secondary building units (SBU) give rise to numerous MOFs with diverse structures. Taking a simple linear dicarboxylate ligand, BDC (BDC = terephthalate), as an example, a series of MOFs (MOF-5, MIL-101, and UIO-66) result from the combination of this ligand with different SBUs (Zn4O; M3O, M = Fe, Al, In, Cr, etc.; and Zr6O4(OH)4). More importantly, MOF structures are significantly diversified when considering the almost infinite number of organic ligands. The geometry and connectivity of a linker often dictates the structure of the resulting MOF. Therefore, adjustments to linker geometry, length, and functional-group can tune the size, shape, and internal surface properties of a MOF for targeted applications.

elements.content: A prominent advantage of MOFs over other traditional porous materials (such as zeolites and mesoporous silica) is their designable structures. The design and prediction of MOF structures can be easily implemented owing to their modular building units with definite geometries and connectivities. The development of reticular chemistry has facilitated the design of MOF structures and the regulation of pore size or pore environment in MOFs through linker elongation or functionalization. For example, the one-dimensional pore apertures in the IRMOF-74 series can be expanded from 10 to 98 Å via a systematic expansion of the organic linkers from one phenylene ring to 11. Meanwhile, by functionalizing the organic linkers, different functional groups can be incorporated into the backbone of a MOF without altering the framework structure. In the field of reticular chemistry, topological analysis is often used to guide the design and prediction of MOF structures. By combining inorganic SBUs and organic linkers with well-defined geometries, the resulting network topology and therefore the MOF structure can be predicted. This method is especially useful to predict simple MOF structures based on ditopic linkers. However, for more complicated multitopic ligands, flexible conformations and geometries make it exceedingly challenging to predict the topology and the structure of the resulting MOFs. Indeed, different symmetries and geometries adopted by the same ligand also play an important role in the variety of MOF structures. For instance, porous coordination network (PCN)-222 is a mesoporous Zr-MOF constructed from 4-connected porphyrinic tetracarboxylate ligands and 8-connected Zr6 clusters with a csq topology, while the microporous isomer PCN-225 features a sqc net when the ligand adopts a different symmetry from that in PCN-222. Similarly, the connection of a tetratopic 1,3,6,8-(p-benzoate)­pyrene linker with 8-connected Zr6 clusters can lead to the generation of both NU-1000 with csq topology and NU-901 with scu topology. Although composed of identical ligands and metal clusters, these MOFs show different properties in gas uptake, catalysis, and light harvesting. Therefore, it is important to understand the mechanism for the formation of different structures and to control the targeted structure for specific applications.
elements.clean_text: A prominent advantage of MOFs over other traditional porous materials (such as zeolites and mesoporous silica) is their designable structures. The design and prediction of MOF structures can be easily implemented owing to their modular building units with definite geometries and connectivities. The development of reticular chemistry has facilitated the design of MOF structures and the regulation of pore size or pore environment in MOFs through linker elongation or functionalization. For example, the one-dimensional pore apertures in the IRMOF-74 series can be expanded from 10 to 98 Å via a systematic expansion of the organic linkers from one phenylene ring to 11. Meanwhile, by functionalizing the organic linkers, different functional groups can be incorporated into the backbone of a MOF without altering the framework structure. In the field of reticular chemistry, topological analysis is often used to guide the design and prediction of MOF structures. By combining inorganic SBUs and organic linkers with well-defined geometries, the resulting network topology and therefore the MOF structure can be predicted. This method is especially useful to predict simple MOF structures based on ditopic linkers. However, for more complicated multitopic ligands, flexible conformations and geometries make it exceedingly challenging to predict the topology and the structure of the resulting MOFs. Indeed, different symmetries and geometries adopted by the same ligand also play an important role in the variety of MOF structures. For instance, porous coordination network (PCN)-222 is a mesoporous Zr-MOF constructed from 4-connected porphyrinic tetracarboxylate ligands and 8-connected Zr6 clusters with a csq topology, while the microporous isomer PCN-225 features a sqc net when the ligand adopts a different symmetry from that in PCN-222. Similarly, the connection of a tetratopic 1,3,6,8-(p-benzoate)pyrene linker with 8-connected Zr6 clusters can lead to the generation of both NU-1000 with csq topology and NU-901 with scu topology. Although composed of identical ligands and metal clusters, these MOFs show different properties in gas uptake, catalysis, and light harvesting. Therefore, it is important to understand the mechanism for the formation of different structures and to control the targeted structure for specific applications.

elements.content: A recent report by Matzger and co-workers has discussed the effects of linker geometry and flexibility on the formation of different Zr-tetratopic carboxylate MOFs. They demonstrated that Zr-MOFs with csq topology can be targeted by designing rectangular-shaped linkers with high aspect ratios. However, the shapes and aspect ratios of linkers are almost identical in csq- and scu-type frameworks. The fundamental factors that control the formation of different nets by the same ligand are still not fully understood. Herein, we design a series of tetratopic carboxylate ligands with similar backbones but different substituents to control the selectivity toward different structures and to understand their formation mechanisms.
elements.clean_text: A recent report by Matzger and co-workers has discussed the effects of linker geometry and flexibility on the formation of different Zr-tetratopic carboxylate MOFs. They demonstrated that Zr-MOFs with csq topology can be targeted by designing rectangular-shaped linkers with high aspect ratios. However, the shapes and aspect ratios of linkers are almost identical in csq- and scu-type frameworks. The fundamental factors that control the formation of different nets by the same ligand are still not fully understood. Herein, we design a series of tetratopic carboxylate ligands with similar backbones but different substituents to control the selectivity toward different structures and to understand their formation mechanisms.

elements.content: We selected seven ligands with different substituents to construct a series of (4,8)-connected Zr-MOFs with three type of topologies, i.e., flu, scu, and csq net (). As shown in a, substituents with different steric hindrance were introduced at the R1 and R2 positions to control the rotation of position 1 and 2, respectively. The products that can be synthesized by different linkers are summarized in . Generally, L1 and L2 give rise to the PCN-605 structure with flu topology exclusively. L3, L4, L5, and L6 were able to form both PCN-606 (scu net) and PCN-608 (csq net) under different synthetic conditions. However, PCN-606 formed by L3, L4, and L5 were often obtained in accompaniment with a small amount PCN-605 as impurity. L6 is a strictly planar linker and therefore avoided the formation of PCN-605. In addition, pure PCN-608 was always isolated with L7 ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

MOF Synthesis and Structural Description

We selected seven ligands with different substituents to construct a series of (4,8)-connected Zr-MOFs with three type of topologies, i.e., flu, scu, and csq net (). As shown in a, substituents with different steric hindrance were introduced at the R1 and R2 positions to control the rotation of position 1 and 2, respectively. The products that can be synthesized by different linkers are summarized in . Generally, L1 and L2 give rise to the PCN-605 structure with flu topology exclusively. L3, L4, L5, and L6 were able to form both PCN-606 (scu net) and PCN-608 (csq net) under different synthetic conditions. However, PCN-606 formed by L3, L4, and L5 were often obtained in accompaniment with a small amount PCN-605 as impurity. L6 is a strictly planar linker and therefore avoided the formation of PCN-605. In addition, pure PCN-608 was always isolated with L7 ligands.

elements.content: Construction of the Zr-MOFs with three types of topologies. (a, b) Structure of the Zr6 cluster and the tetratopic ligands. (c, d, e) Three types of symmetries (D 2, C 2h and C 2v ) adopted by the ligands. (f, g, h) Topologies and structures of the Zr-MOFs. Black C, red O, blue Zr.
elements.clean_text: 1  Construction of the Zr-MOFs with three types of topologies. (a, b) Structure of the Zr6 cluster and the tetratopic ligands. (c, d, e) Three types of symmetries (D 2, C 2h  and C 2v ) adopted by the ligands. (f, g, h) Topologies and structures of the Zr-MOFs. Black C, red O, blue Zr.

elements.content: When L1 and L2 were adopted, MOFs with the flu topology were always obtained, which were named PCN-605-H and PCN-605-OH. It has been reported that L1 with no substituents tends to adopt a T d symmetry in MOFs as a result of the rotating C–C bond in the inner biphenyl group. Obviously, substituting the H group by a bulkier OH group in the R1 position would increase the dihedral angle between the two inner phenyl rings. In fact, the dihedral angle between the two inner phenyl rings increases from 41.09° to 44.72° in PCN-605-H and PCN-605-OH. Meanwhile, the 8-connected Zr6 cluster can be regarded as a cubic node. Therefore, PCN-605-H and PCN-605-OH adopt a (4,8)-connected network with flu topology. Note that UMCM-312 with a structure similar to PCN-605-H and PCN-605-OH has been previously reported by Matzger and co-workers.
elements.clean_text: When L1 and L2 were adopted, MOFs with the flu topology were always obtained, which were named PCN-605-H and PCN-605-OH. It has been reported that L1 with no substituents tends to adopt a T  d  symmetry in MOFs as a result of the rotating C-C bond in the inner biphenyl group. Obviously, substituting the H group by a bulkier OH group in the R1 position would increase the dihedral angle between the two inner phenyl rings. In fact, the dihedral angle between the two inner phenyl rings increases from 41.09° to 44.72° in PCN-605-H and PCN-605-OH. Meanwhile, the 8-connected Zr6 cluster can be regarded as a cubic node. Therefore, PCN-605-H and PCN-605-OH adopt a (4,8)-connected network with flu topology. Note that UMCM-312 with a structure similar to PCN-605-H and PCN-605-OH has been previously reported by Matzger and co-workers.

elements.content: A D 2h symmetry node may be obtained if the central part of the tetratopic ligand is coplanar. By replacing the inner biphenyl group with a pyrene moiety, the geometry of the tetratopic ligand can be fixed to rectangular planar. Topologically, a (4,8)-connected scu net can be obtained by connecting rectangular planar nodes (ligands) and cubic nodes (Zr6 clusters). In fact, this structure has been reported as NU-901. In theory, if hydroxyl groups were introduced to the 4,4′-positions of the biphenyl group, the dihedral angle between the two phenyl rings may reduce close to zero. It has also been confirmed in our previous work that the inner biphenyl group in the 4,4′-methoxyl substituted ligand is coplanar in the other MOFs (FJI-H8 and FJI-H11 series), which may be due to conjugative effects. As expected, the 4,4′-substituted ligand L3, L4, and L5 can form scu-type MOFs when combined with 8-connected Zr6 clusters. They are named PCN-606-OH, -NH2 and -OMe, respectively. It should be noted that L3, L4, and L5 can also adopt T d symmetry by rotating the inner biphenyl moiety. As a result, a handful of flu networks were always obtained as impurities along with the formation of scu-type MOFs.
elements.clean_text: A D 2h  symmetry node may be obtained if the central part of the tetratopic ligand is coplanar. By replacing the inner biphenyl group with a pyrene moiety, the geometry of the tetratopic ligand can be fixed to rectangular planar. Topologically, a (4,8)-connected scu net can be obtained by connecting rectangular planar nodes (ligands) and cubic nodes (Zr6 clusters). In fact, this structure has been reported as NU-901. In theory, if hydroxyl groups were introduced to the 4,4'-positions of the biphenyl group, the dihedral angle between the two phenyl rings may reduce close to zero. It has also been confirmed in our previous work that the inner biphenyl group in the 4,4'-methoxyl substituted ligand is coplanar in the other MOFs (FJI-H8 and FJI-H11 series), which may be due to conjugative effects. As expected, the 4,4'-substituted ligand L3, L4, and L5 can form scu-type MOFs when combined with 8-connected Zr6 clusters. They are named PCN-606-OH, -NH2 and -OMe, respectively. It should be noted that L3, L4, and L5 can also adopt T  d  symmetry by rotating the inner biphenyl moiety. As a result, a handful of flu networks were always obtained as impurities along with the formation of scu-type MOFs.

elements.content: Besides flu- and scu-type networks, another well-known (4,8)-c net is the csq framework. Different from the D 2 and C 2h symmetries in the flu- and scu-type networks (respectively), the 4-connected node of csq topology is in the C 2v symmetry. For example, the well-known mesoporous MOF, NU-1000, reported by Hupp and co-workers was also constructed by the 8-connected Zr6 cluster and the 4-connected central coplanar tetratopic carboxylate ligand. Differing from the PCN-605 and PCN-606 series, NU-1000 adopts a (4,8)-c csq net topology. By careful control of the reaction conditions, we managed to obtain csq topology frameworks using L3 to L7, namely PCN-608-OH, PCN-608-NH2, PCN-608-OMe, Nu-1000, and PCN-608-OCp (-OCp = cyclopentyloxyl group). Although they are based on the same 8-connected Zr6 clusters and similar 4-connected linkers, the three MOF topologies show different flexibilities and porosities. The flu and scu MOFs are microporous, highly flexible frameworks while the csq MOF is a mesoporous network with outstanding rigidity and stability.
elements.clean_text: Besides flu- and scu-type networks, another well-known (4,8)-c net is the csq framework. Different from the D 2 and C 2h  symmetries in the flu- and scu-type networks (respectively), the 4-connected node of csq topology is in the C 2v  symmetry. For example, the well-known mesoporous MOF, NU-1000, reported by Hupp and co-workers was also constructed by the 8-connected Zr6 cluster and the 4-connected central coplanar tetratopic carboxylate ligand. Differing from the PCN-605 and PCN-606 series, NU-1000 adopts a (4,8)-c csq net topology. By careful control of the reaction conditions, we managed to obtain csq topology frameworks using L3 to L7, namely PCN-608-OH, PCN-608-NH2, PCN-608-OMe, Nu-1000, and PCN-608-OCp (-OCp = cyclopentyloxyl group). Although they are based on the same 8-connected Zr6 clusters and similar 4-connected linkers, the three MOF topologies show different flexibilities and porosities. The flu and scu MOFs are microporous, highly flexible frameworks while the csq MOF is a mesoporous network with outstanding rigidity and stability.

elements.content: The structures of PCN-605, 606, and 608 are depicted in f, g, and h. PCN-605 is composed of large octahedral cavities surrounded by small windows. PCN-606 possesses uniform channels with a diameter of 12 Å. PCN-608 is hierarchically porous with mesoporous channels of 33 Å and microporous channels of 10 Å. The porosity of the PCN-605, PCN-606, and PCN-608 series are estimated by N2 sorption isotherms (Figure S5). Both PCN-605 and 606 exhibits flexible behaviors as reflected by the shifted XRD peaks upon desolvation, whereas PCN-608 is a rigid framework (Figure S6). Since different structures are required for specific applications, it is important to control the selectivity toward different structures and to understand their formation mechanisms.
elements.clean_text: The structures of PCN-605, 606, and 608 are depicted in f, g, and h. PCN-605 is composed of large octahedral cavities surrounded by small windows. PCN-606 possesses uniform channels with a diameter of 12 Å. PCN-608 is hierarchically porous with mesoporous channels of 33 Å and microporous channels of 10 Å. The porosity of the PCN-605, PCN-606, and PCN-608 series are estimated by N2 sorption isotherms (Figure S5). Both PCN-605 and 606 exhibits flexible behaviors as reflected by the shifted XRD peaks upon desolvation, whereas PCN-608 is a rigid framework (Figure S6). Since different structures are required for specific applications, it is important to control the selectivity toward different structures and to understand their formation mechanisms.

elements.content: In order to investigate the differences among the three classes of Zr-MOFs based on similar ligands, the structures were carefully analyzed. Evidently, the Zr6 clusters in all of the above-mentioned MOFs are all the same. Therefore, the topology of the frameworks depended on the conformations of the tetratopic ligands. As shown in , the dihedral angles between the outer phenyl rings (with carboxylate groups) and the inner phenyl rings are the same in the flu and scu net frameworks, while the dihedral angles between the two inner phenyl rings are different. As a result, the ligand in the PCN-605 series adopts tetrahedral conformations while the ligand in the PCN-606 series adopts rectangular planar conformations. Therefore, PCN-605 can be easily obtained by introducing bulky substituents at the R1 position on the linkers, as verified by the case of L2.
elements.clean_text:
Formation Mechanism of Different Structures

In order to investigate the differences among the three classes of Zr-MOFs based on similar ligands, the structures were carefully analyzed. Evidently, the Zr6 clusters in all of the above-mentioned MOFs are all the same. Therefore, the topology of the frameworks depended on the conformations of the tetratopic ligands. As shown in , the dihedral angles between the outer phenyl rings (with carboxylate groups) and the inner phenyl rings are the same in the flu and scu net frameworks, while the dihedral angles between the two inner phenyl rings are different. As a result, the ligand in the PCN-605 series adopts tetrahedral conformations while the ligand in the PCN-606 series adopts rectangular planar conformations. Therefore, PCN-605 can be easily obtained by introducing bulky substituents at the R1 position on the linkers, as verified by the case of L2.

elements.content: Conformations of the three classes of tetratopic ligands in MOFs. (a, d) Conformation of the tetrahedral ligand in the flu net framework. (b, e) Conformation of the rectangular planar ligand in the scu net framework. (c, f) Conformation of the rectangular planar ligand in the csq net framework. Orange line: the relative orientation of the two inner phenyl rings. Blue line: the relative orientation of the outer phenyl rings compared to the inner phenyl rings. Black: C; red: O; yellow and blue: substituents.
elements.clean_text: 2  Conformations of the three classes of tetratopic ligands in MOFs. (a, d) Conformation of the tetrahedral ligand in the flu net framework. (b, e) Conformation of the rectangular planar ligand in the scu net framework. (c, f) Conformation of the rectangular planar ligand in the csq net framework. Orange line: the relative orientation of the two inner phenyl rings. Blue line: the relative orientation of the outer phenyl rings compared to the inner phenyl rings. Black: C; red: O; yellow and blue: substituents.

elements.content: The dihedral angles between the two inner phenyl rings of the ligand series are close to zero in both PCN-606 and PCN-608. However, the dihedral angles between the outer phenyl rings and the inner phenyl rings are different in the scu and csq net frameworks, which leads to the formation of the two different structures. Evidently, the pocket formed by two outer phenyl rings in PCN-608 is larger than that in PCN-606, which can accommodate larger substituents at the R2 position. Therefore, PCN-608 would be the preferred product when bulky substituents are introduced at the R2 position. This is consistent with the experimental results that predict L7 with cyclopentyloxyl group forms PCN-608 exclusively.
elements.clean_text: The dihedral angles between the two inner phenyl rings of the ligand series are close to zero in both PCN-606 and PCN-608. However, the dihedral angles between the outer phenyl rings and the inner phenyl rings are different in the scu and csq net frameworks, which leads to the formation of the two different structures. Evidently, the pocket formed by two outer phenyl rings in PCN-608 is larger than that in PCN-606, which can accommodate larger substituents at the R2 position. Therefore, PCN-608 would be the preferred product when bulky substituents are introduced at the R2 position. This is consistent with the experimental results that predict L7 with cyclopentyloxyl group forms PCN-608 exclusively.

elements.content: To assess our hypothesis and further understand the formation mechanism for each product, we turned to molecular simulations. Since the Zr6 clusters in PCN-605, 606, and 608 all share the same geometry, composition, and connectivity, the energy difference between each structure is attributed to the conformation of the linkers. The energies of the linkers in PCN-605, 606, and 608 were calculated and summarized in . For comparison, they were normalized by subtracting the lowest energy of a given linker. Clearly, L1 and L2 have a much lower energy in PCN-605 compared with other conformations. L2, with bulkier substituents in the R1 position, suffers a higher energy penalty to form the coplanar conformation. Meanwhile, the energy levels of L3, L5, and L6 are similar in PCN-606 and PCN-608, which is in line with the observation that both PCN-606 and PCN-608 can be obtained using these ligands. The introduction of a bulky cyclopentyloxyl group significantly increases the energy of L7 in PCN-605 and PCN-606. Therefore, PCN-608 was obtained exclusively using L7 under all attempted synthetic conditions. It should be pointed out that the comparison of linker energy is a simplified model to understand the complicated formation processes of MOFs. In reality, the calculation of MOF formation energies would be much more complicated than a simulation of linker energy. Factors such as solvent, temperature, water content, and modulating reagent need to be considered, which will not be discussed in this work.
elements.clean_text:
Molecular Simulations

To assess our hypothesis and further understand the formation mechanism for each product, we turned to molecular simulations. Since the Zr6 clusters in PCN-605, 606, and 608 all share the same geometry, composition, and connectivity, the energy difference between each structure is attributed to the conformation of the linkers. The energies of the linkers in PCN-605, 606, and 608 were calculated and summarized in . For comparison, they were normalized by subtracting the lowest energy of a given linker. Clearly, L1 and L2 have a much lower energy in PCN-605 compared with other conformations. L2, with bulkier substituents in the R1 position, suffers a higher energy penalty to form the coplanar conformation. Meanwhile, the energy levels of L3, L5, and L6 are similar in PCN-606 and PCN-608, which is in line with the observation that both PCN-606 and PCN-608 can be obtained using these ligands. The introduction of a bulky cyclopentyloxyl group significantly increases the energy of L7 in PCN-605 and PCN-606. Therefore, PCN-608 was obtained exclusively using L7 under all attempted synthetic conditions. It should be pointed out that the comparison of linker energy is a simplified model to understand the complicated formation processes of MOFs. In reality, the calculation of MOF formation energies would be much more complicated than a simulation of linker energy. Factors such as solvent, temperature, water content, and modulating reagent need to be considered, which will not be discussed in this work.

elements.content: Calculated relative energies for the selected ligands in MOFs with different topologies. The relative ligand energies are normalized by subtracting the lowest energy of a given ligand. For clarity, the MOF-ligand combination with a relative energy of zero is shown below the zero point line. Related data are listed in Table S2.
elements.clean_text: 3  Calculated relative energies for the selected ligands in MOFs with different topologies. The relative ligand energies are normalized by subtracting the lowest energy of a given ligand. For clarity, the MOF-ligand combination with a relative energy of zero is shown below the zero point line. Related data are listed in Table S2.

elements.content: Experimental results in combination with those of simulations have allowed us to control the formation of different structures by judicious selection of linkers with different steric effects at specific positions. Since the functional groups on the linkers primarily dictate the structure of the MOF, the possible functional groups that can be incorporated to form a specific MOF structure are limited. For example, only L1 and L2 can form pure PCN-605, whereas other functional groups, such as amino-groups, prohibit the adoption of the PCN-605 structure. However, amino-groups are commonly adopted as chemical handles preanchored on the linkers of MOFs for subsequent modifications. Meanwhile, it is always difficult to form PCN-608 from L1 because of the rotation of biphenyl groups. Guided by the formation mechanism of each phase, the mixed linker strategy could restrict the rotation of linkers and therefore obtain the preferred product with the desired functional groups (). As a proof of concept, L1 was mixed with L4 which gave rise to amino-functionalized PCN-605 (termed mixed linker porous coordination network (MLPCN)-605). Doping a small amount of L6 with L1 will force the biphenyl groups into a coplanar conformation which leads to the formation of a mixture of PCN-606 and PCN-608 (termed MLPCN-608–1). By further addition of L7 to limit the rotation of the C–C bond at position 2, pure PCN-608 could be obtained (termed MLPCN-608–2). Interestingly, although NU-1000, formed by L6, exhibits the same structure as PCN-608, it always contains a small amount of PCN-606 impurity as reflected by the residual electron density at the center of the hexagonal channel. By mixing L6 with L7, pure PCN-608 can be generated.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Control of MOF Topologies

Experimental results in combination with those of simulations have allowed us to control the formation of different structures by judicious selection of linkers with different steric effects at specific positions. Since the functional groups on the linkers primarily dictate the structure of the MOF, the possible functional groups that can be incorporated to form a specific MOF structure are limited. For example, only L1 and L2 can form pure PCN-605, whereas other functional groups, such as amino-groups, prohibit the adoption of the PCN-605 structure. However, amino-groups are commonly adopted as chemical handles preanchored on the linkers of MOFs for subsequent modifications. Meanwhile, it is always difficult to form PCN-608 from L1 because of the rotation of biphenyl groups. Guided by the formation mechanism of each phase, the mixed linker strategy could restrict the rotation of linkers and therefore obtain the preferred product with the desired functional groups (). As a proof of concept, L1 was mixed with L4 which gave rise to amino-functionalized PCN-605 (termed mixed linker porous coordination network (MLPCN)-605). Doping a small amount of L6 with L1 will force the biphenyl groups into a coplanar conformation which leads to the formation of a mixture of PCN-606 and PCN-608 (termed MLPCN-608-1). By further addition of L7 to limit the rotation of the C-C bond at position 2, pure PCN-608 could be obtained (termed MLPCN-608-2). Interestingly, although NU-1000, formed by L6, exhibits the same structure as PCN-608, it always contains a small amount of PCN-606 impurity as reflected by the residual electron density at the center of the hexagonal channel. By mixing L6 with L7, pure PCN-608 can be generated.

elements.content: Controllable construction of specific topology MOFs via the mixed linker strategy. Black: C; Red: O; Blue: Zr.
elements.clean_text: 4  Controllable construction of specific topology MOFs via the mixed linker strategy. Black: C; Red: O; Blue: Zr.

elements.content: As has been confirmed by the above-mentioned experiments, the combination of a set of linkers with different steric effects at specific positions will provide a new level of control toward the MOF structures. By carefully designing and selecting the appropriate ligands, a lot of reported, intriguing MOFs can be functionalized via the mixed linker strategy. Furthermore, unprecedented structures may be obtained, taking advantage of the combination of different linkers.
elements.clean_text: As has been confirmed by the above-mentioned experiments, the combination of a set of linkers with different steric effects at specific positions will provide a new level of control toward the MOF structures. By carefully designing and selecting the appropriate ligands, a lot of reported, intriguing MOFs can be functionalized via the mixed linker strategy. Furthermore, unprecedented structures may be obtained, taking advantage of the combination of different linkers.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have designed and synthesized seven tetratopic carboxylate ligands with the same backbones but different substituents. A series of (4,8)-connected Zr-MOFs with three types of topologies were constructed from these ligands due to the different symmetries adopted by the ligands. Careful analysis of the structures shows that formation of the different MOFs depends on the steric hindrance effect of the substituents on the ligands. This effect has also been confirmed by molecular simulation. On this basis, specific structures can be obtained using the mixed linker strategy by judiciously selecting combinations of linkers. Our systematic research sheds light on the precise design and synthesis of desired MOF structures for specific applications.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we have designed and synthesized seven tetratopic carboxylate ligands with the same backbones but different substituents. A series of (4,8)-connected Zr-MOFs with three types of topologies were constructed from these ligands due to the different symmetries adopted by the ligands. Careful analysis of the structures shows that formation of the different MOFs depends on the steric hindrance effect of the substituents on the ligands. This effect has also been confirmed by molecular simulation. On this basis, specific structures can be obtained using the mixed linker strategy by judiciously selecting combinations of linkers. Our systematic research sheds light on the precise design and synthesis of desired MOF structures for specific applications.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents used in synthetic studies were commercially available and used as supplied without further purification. The ligands were synthesized through the routines in Schemes S1–S6. 1H NMR spectra were obtained on a Mercury 300 MHz spectrometer. Single crystal X-ray diffraction experiments were carried out on Bruker D8-Venture diffractometers equipped with a Cu sealed tube (λ = 1.54178 Å) and a Rigaku SuperNova diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was carried out with a Bruker D8-Focus Bragg–Brentano X-ray Powder Diffractometer equipped with a Cu sealed tube (λ = 1.54178 Å) at 40 kV and 40 mA. Gas sorption measurements were conducted on a Micrometritics ASAP 2020 system.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Instrumentation

All reagents and solvents used in synthetic studies were commercially available and used as supplied without further purification. The ligands were synthesized through the routines in Schemes S1-S6. 1H NMR spectra were obtained on a Mercury 300 MHz spectrometer. Single crystal X-ray diffraction experiments were carried out on Bruker D8-Venture diffractometers equipped with a Cu sealed tube (λ = 1.54178 Å) and a Rigaku SuperNova diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was carried out with a Bruker D8-Focus Bragg-Brentano X-ray Powder Diffractometer equipped with a Cu sealed tube (λ = 1.54178 Å) at 40 kV and 40 mA. Gas sorption measurements were conducted on a Micrometritics ASAP 2020 system.

Synthesis of MOF MLPCN-608-2

elements.content: For ligands L3, L4, and L5, all three topologies of Zr-MOFs can be obtained under various synthetic conditions. When benzoic acid was added to adjust the pH of the reaction mixture, PCN-606 can be obtained as the main product along with a small amount of PCN-605 as an impurity. However, when the stronger trifluoroacetic acid was applied to adjust the pH of the reaction mixture, PCN-608 can be obtained with a small amount of PCN-606 as a byproduct. Presumably the acidity of the reaction mixture plays a vital role in the selective synthesis of the Zr-MOFs with different topologies.
elements.clean_text:
Selective Synthesis of Zr-MOFs

For ligands L3, L4, and L5, all three topologies of Zr-MOFs can be obtained under various synthetic conditions. When benzoic acid was added to adjust the pH of the reaction mixture, PCN-606 can be obtained as the main product along with a small amount of PCN-605 as an impurity. However, when the stronger trifluoroacetic acid was applied to adjust the pH of the reaction mixture, PCN-608 can be obtained with a small amount of PCN-606 as a byproduct. Presumably the acidity of the reaction mixture plays a vital role in the selective synthesis of the Zr-MOFs with different topologies.

elements.content: All single crystals were taken from the mother liquid without further treatment, transferred to oil, and mounted onto a loop for single crystal X-ray data collection. For PCN-605-H, PCN-605-OH, PCN-606-OH, PCN-606-NH2, PCN-606-OMe, and PCN-608-OCp, diffractions were measured on Bruker Smart Apex diffractometers equipped with a Cu Kα sealed-tube X-ray source (λ = 1.54178 Å, graphite monochromated) and low temperature device (100 K). For PCN-608-OH, MLPCN-608–1, and MLPCN-608–2, diffractions were measured on Bruker Smart Apex diffractometers equipped with a Cu Kα sealed-tube X-ray source (λ = 1.54178 Å, graphite monochromated) and room temperature device (∼296 K). For PCN-608-NH2 and MLPCN-605, diffractions were measured on Rigaku SuperNova diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å, graphite monochromated) and low temperature device (100 K). The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using SHELXL software. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The hydrogen atoms on the aromatic rings were located at geometrically calculated positions and refined by riding. Free solvent molecules are highly disordered in MOFs, and attempts to locate and refine the solvent peaks were unsuccessful. It should be noted that the large substituents (cyclopentyloxyl group) on L7 in PCN-608-OCp and MLPCN-608–2 are seriously disordered. Therefore, it was impossible to localize the flexible cyclopentyloxyl group in the electron density map. Only the oxygen atoms, which are directly connected to the phenyl ring, were localized. The diffused electron densities resulting from these solvent molecules were removed using the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON; structures were then refined again using the data generated. Crystal data are summarized in Tables S3–S6. CCDC 1569627, 1569630, 1569632–1569634 and 1572660–1572665 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Crystallography

All single crystals were taken from the mother liquid without further treatment, transferred to oil, and mounted onto a loop for single crystal X-ray data collection. For PCN-605-H, PCN-605-OH, PCN-606-OH, PCN-606-NH2, PCN-606-OMe, and PCN-608-OCp, diffractions were measured on Bruker Smart Apex diffractometers equipped with a Cu Kα sealed-tube X-ray source (λ = 1.54178 Å, graphite monochromated) and low temperature device (100 K). For PCN-608-OH, MLPCN-608-1, and MLPCN-608-2, diffractions were measured on Bruker Smart Apex diffractometers equipped with a Cu Kα sealed-tube X-ray source (λ = 1.54178 Å, graphite monochromated) and room temperature device (~296 K). For PCN-608-NH2 and MLPCN-605, diffractions were measured on Rigaku SuperNova diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å, graphite monochromated) and low temperature device (100 K). The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using SHELXL software. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The hydrogen atoms on the aromatic rings were located at geometrically calculated positions and refined by riding. Free solvent molecules are highly disordered in MOFs, and attempts to locate and refine the solvent peaks were unsuccessful. It should be noted that the large substituents (cyclopentyloxyl group) on L7 in PCN-608-OCp and MLPCN-608-2 are seriously disordered. Therefore, it was impossible to localize the flexible cyclopentyloxyl group in the electron density map. Only the oxygen atoms, which are directly connected to the phenyl ring, were localized. The diffused electron densities resulting from these solvent molecules were removed using the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON; structures were then refined again using the data generated. Crystal data are summarized in Tables S3-S6. CCDC 1569627, 1569630, 1569632-1569634 and 1572660-1572665 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre.

elements.content: N2 adsorption measurements were performed using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface area and pore size analyzer. Before sorption experiments, as-synthesized samples were washed with DMF several times to remove unreacted starting ligands and inorganic species. Afterward, the crystals were carefully decanted and washed with DMF and acetone several times. Then the samples of PCN-605-H, PCN-605-OH, PCN-606-OH, PCN-606-NH2, PCN-606-OMe, and MLPCN-605 were activated by supercritical CO2. After that, the samples were further activated under vacuum at 80 °C for 5 h. The other samples were activated under vacuum at 80 °C for 10 h after acetone exchange. Low-pressure N2 adsorption isotherms were measured at 77 K in a liquid nitrogen bath. The specific surface areas were determined using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller model from the N2 sorption data. For the N2 sorption isotherms, please see Figure S5.
elements.clean_text:
N2 Sorption Measurements

N2 adsorption measurements were performed using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface area and pore size analyzer. Before sorption experiments, as-synthesized samples were washed with DMF several times to remove unreacted starting ligands and inorganic species. Afterward, the crystals were carefully decanted and washed with DMF and acetone several times. Then the samples of PCN-605-H, PCN-605-OH, PCN-606-OH, PCN-606-NH2, PCN-606-OMe, and MLPCN-605 were activated by supercritical CO2. After that, the samples were further activated under vacuum at 80 °C for 5 h. The other samples were activated under vacuum at 80 °C for 10 h after acetone exchange. Low-pressure N2 adsorption isotherms were measured at 77 K in a liquid nitrogen bath. The specific surface areas were determined using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller model from the N2 sorption data. For the N2 sorption isotherms, please see Figure S5.

elements.content: To provide guidance for the interpretation of the experimental work, a density functional theory (DFT) study was performed to examine the relative stabilities and the frontier molecular orbitals for the ligand fragments that possessed different symmetries. The carboxylates of linkers were replaced by H to balance the charge. The computations were performed with the DMol3 programs of Materials Studio 6.0.13. The Local Density Approximation (LDA)-PWC functional and DND 3.5 basis were employed for all calculations. In addition, the equilibrium geometries and energy of model compounds were calculated with the C 2h , C 2v , and D 2 symmetric constraints in the gas phase. During the calculation processes, the default settings embedded in Materials Studio 6.0.13 were used for all calculations. For comparison, the energies of a linker fragment in different conformations were normalized by subtracting the lowest value. The calculated energy of linker fragments are listed in Table S2.
elements.clean_text:
Computational Methods

To provide guidance for the interpretation of the experimental work, a density functional theory (DFT) study was performed to examine the relative stabilities and the frontier molecular orbitals for the ligand fragments that possessed different symmetries. The carboxylates of linkers were replaced by H to balance the charge. The computations were performed with the DMol3 programs of Materials Studio 6.0.13. The Local Density Approximation (LDA)-PWC functional and DND 3.5 basis were employed for all calculations. In addition, the equilibrium geometries and energy of model compounds were calculated with the C 2h , C 2v , and D 2 symmetric constraints in the gas phase. During the calculation processes, the default settings embedded in Materials Studio 6.0.13 were used for all calculations. For comparison, the energies of a linker fragment in different conformations were normalized by subtracting the lowest value. The calculated energy of linker fragments are listed in Table S2.

ZrCl4 (20 mg), 2,2′-H-H4TPCB (L1) (10 mg), benzoic acid (700 mg), and DMF (3 mL) were charged in a Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated in a 120 °C oven for 72 h. After cooling down to room temperature, colorless crystals of PCN-605-H were harvested (yield: 63%).

Synthesis of PCN-605-OH

ZrCl4 (20 mg), 2,2′-OH-H4TPCB (L2) (10 mg), benzoic acid (600 mg), and DMF (3 mL) were charged in a Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated in a 120 °C oven for 72 h. After cooling down to room temperature, yellow crystals of PCN-605-OH were harvested (yield: 68%).

Synthesis of PCN-606-OH

ZrCl4 (20 mg), 4,4′-OH-H4TPCB (L3) (10 mg), benzoic acid (500 mg), and DMF (3 mL) were charged in a Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated in a 120 °C oven for 72 h. After cooling down to room temperature, yellow crystals of PCN-606-OH were harvested (yield: 67%).

Synthesis of PCN-606-NH<sub>2</sub>

ZrCl4 (20 mg), 4,4′-NH2-H4TPCB (L4) (10 mg), benzoic acid (500 mg), and DMF (2 mL) were charged in a Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated in a 120 °C oven for 72 h. After cooling down to room temperature, yellow crystals of PCN-606-NH2 were harvested (yield: 63%).

Synthesis of PCN-606-OMe

ZrCl4 (20 mg), 4,4′-OMe-H4TPCB (L5) (10 mg), benzoic acid (600 mg), and DMF (3 mL) were charged in a Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated in a 120 °C oven for 72 h. After cooling down to room temperature, colorless crystals of PCN-606-OMe were harvested (yield: 65%).

Synthesis of PCN-608-OH

ZrCl4 (20 mg), 4,4′-OH-H4TPCB (L3) (10 mg), trifluoroacetic acid (0.1 mL), and DMF (2.5 mL) were charged in a Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated in a 120 °C oven for 72 h. After cooling down to room temperature, red crystals of PCN-608-OH were harvested (yield: 69%).

Synthesis of PCN-608-NH<sub>2</sub>

ZrCl4 (20 mg), 4,4′-NH2-H4TPCB (L4) (10 mg), trifluoroacetic acid (0.1 mL), and DMF (2.5 mL) were charged in a Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated in a 120 °C oven for 72 h. After cooling down to room temperature, red crystals of PCN-608-NH2 were harvested (yield: 68%).

Synthesis of PCN-608-OMe

ZrCl4 (20 mg), 4,4′-OMe-H4TPCB (L5) (10 mg), trifluoroacetic acid (0.1 mL), and DMF (2.5 mL) were charged in a Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated in a 120 °C oven for 72 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the colorless powder of PCN-608-OMe was harvested (yield: 75%).

Synthesis of PCN-608-OCp

ZrCl4 (20 mg), 4,4′-OCp-H4TPCB (L7) (10 mg), trifluoroacetic acid (0.1 mL), and DMF (2.5 mL) were charged in a Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated in a 120 °C oven for 72 h. After cooling down to room temperature, colorless crystals of PCN-608-OCp were harvested (yield: 66%).

Synthesis of MLPCN-605

ZrCl4 (20 mg), 2,2′-H-H4TPCB (L1) (5 mg), 4,4′-NH2-H4TPCB (L4) (5 mg), benzoic acid (500 mg), and DMF (3 mL) were charged in a Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated in a 120 °C oven for 72 h. After cooling down to room temperature, yellow crystals of MLPCN-605 were harvested (yield: 70%).

Synthesis of MLPCN-608–1

ZrCl4 (20 mg), 2,2′-H-H4TPCB (L1) (5 mg), H4TBAPy (L6) (5 mg), benzoic acid (500 mg), and DMF (3 mL) were charged in a Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated in a 120 °C oven for 72 h. After cooling down to room temperature, yellow crystals of MLPCN-608–1 were harvested (yield: 71%).

Synthesis of MOF MLPCN-608–2

ZrCl4 (20 mg), 2,2′-H-H4TPCB (L1) (3.3 mg), H4TBAPy (L6) (3.3 mg), 4,4′-OCp-H4TPCB (L7) (3.3 mg), benzoic acid (500 mg), and DMF (3 mL) were charged in a Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated in a 120 °C oven for 72 h. After cooling down to room temperature, yellow crystals of MLPCN-608–2 were harvested (yield: 69%).

Synthesis of PCN-606-OH

ZrCl4 (20 mg), 4,4'-OH-H4TPCB (L3) (10 mg), benzoic acid (500 mg), and DMF (3 mL) were charged in a Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated in a 120 °C oven for 72 h. After cooling down to room temperature, yellow crystals of PCN-606-OH were harvested (yield: 67%).

Synthesis of PCN-606-NH2 

ZrCl4 (20 mg), 4,4'-NH2-H4TPCB (L4) (10 mg), benzoic acid (500 mg), and DMF (2 mL) were charged in a Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated in a 120 °C oven for 72 h. After cooling down to room temperature, yellow crystals of PCN-606-NH2 were harvested (yield: 63%).

ZrCl4 (20 mg), 4,4'-OMe-H4TPCB (L5) (10 mg), benzoic acid (600 mg), and DMF (3 mL) were charged in a Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated in a 120 °C oven for 72 h. After cooling down to room temperature, colorless crystals of PCN-606-OMe were harvested (yield: 65%).

Synthesis of PCN-608-OH

ZrCl4 (20 mg), 4,4'-OH-H4TPCB (L3) (10 mg), trifluoroacetic acid (0.1 mL), and DMF (2.5 mL) were charged in a Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated in a 120 °C oven for 72 h. After cooling down to room temperature, red crystals of PCN-608-OH were harvested (yield: 69%).

Synthesis of PCN-608-NH2 

ZrCl4 (20 mg), 4,4'-NH2-H4TPCB (L4) (10 mg), trifluoroacetic acid (0.1 mL), and DMF (2.5 mL) were charged in a Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated in a 120 °C oven for 72 h. After cooling down to room temperature, red crystals of PCN-608-NH2 were harvested (yield: 68%).

Synthesis of PCN-608-OMe

ZrCl4 (20 mg), 4,4'-OMe-H4TPCB (L5) (10 mg), trifluoroacetic acid (0.1 mL), and DMF (2.5 mL) were charged in a Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated in a 120 °C oven for 72 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the colorless powder of PCN-608-OMe was harvested (yield: 75%).

Synthesis of PCN-608-OCp

ZrCl4 (20 mg), 4,4'-OCp-H4TPCB (L7) (10 mg), trifluoroacetic acid (0.1 mL), and DMF (2.5 mL) were charged in a Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated in a 120 °C oven for 72 h. After cooling down to room temperature, colorless crystals of PCN-608-OCp were harvested (yield: 66%).

Synthesis of MLPCN-605

ZrCl4 (20 mg), 2,2'-H-H4TPCB (L1) (5 mg), 4,4'-NH2-H4TPCB (L4) (5 mg), benzoic acid (500 mg), and DMF (3 mL) were charged in a Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated in a 120 °C oven for 72 h. After cooling down to room temperature, yellow crystals of MLPCN-605 were harvested (yield: 70%).

Synthesis of MLPCN-608-1

ZrCl4 (20 mg), 2,2'-H-H4TPCB (L1) (5 mg), H4TBAPy (L6) (5 mg), benzoic acid (500 mg), and DMF (3 mL) were charged in a Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated in a 120 °C oven for 72 h. After cooling down to room temperature, yellow crystals of MLPCN-608-1 were harvested (yield: 71%).

Synthesis of MOF MLPCN-608-2

ZrCl4 (20 mg), 2,2'-H-H4TPCB (L1) (3.3 mg), H4TBAPy (L6) (3.3 mg), 4,4'-OCp-H4TPCB (L7) (3.3 mg), benzoic acid (500 mg), and DMF (3 mL) were charged in a Pyrex vial. The mixture was heated in a 120 °C oven for 72 h. After cooling down to room temperature, yellow crystals of MLPCN-608-2 were harvested (yield: 69%).

cln_elements.content: Construction of the Zr-MOFs with three types of topologies. (a, b) Structure of the Zr6 cluster and the tetratopic ligands. (c, d, e) Three types of symmetries (D 2, C 2h and C 2v ) adopted by the ligands. (f, g, h) Topologies and structures of the Zr-MOFs. Black C, red O, blue Zr.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Construction of the Zr-MOFs with three types of topologies. (a, b) Structure of the Zr6 cluster and the tetratopic ligands. (c, d, e) Three types of symmetries (D 2, C 2h  and C 2v ) adopted by the ligands. (f, g, h) Topologies and structures of the Zr-MOFs. Black C, red O, blue Zr.

cln_elements.content: Conformations of the three classes of tetratopic ligands in MOFs. (a, d) Conformation of the tetrahedral ligand in the flu net framework. (b, e) Conformation of the rectangular planar ligand in the scu net framework. (c, f) Conformation of the rectangular planar ligand in the csq net framework. Orange line: the relative orientation of the two inner phenyl rings. Blue line: the relative orientation of the outer phenyl rings compared to the inner phenyl rings. Black: C; red: O; yellow and blue: substituents.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Conformations of the three classes of tetratopic ligands in MOFs. (a, d) Conformation of the tetrahedral ligand in the flu net framework. (b, e) Conformation of the rectangular planar ligand in the scu net framework. (c, f) Conformation of the rectangular planar ligand in the csq net framework. Orange line: the relative orientation of the two inner phenyl rings. Blue line: the relative orientation of the outer phenyl rings compared to the inner phenyl rings. Black: C; red: O; yellow and blue: substituents.

cln_elements.content: Calculated relative energies for the selected ligands in MOFs with different topologies. The relative ligand energies are normalized by subtracting the lowest energy of a given ligand. For clarity, the MOF-ligand combination with a relative energy of zero is shown below the zero point line. Related data are listed in Table S2.

metadata.title:
Control
the Structure of Zr-Tetracarboxylate Frameworks
through Steric Tuning
